title: Anyonic Lie algebra
summary: In mathematics, an anyonic Lie algebra is a U(1) graded vector space L {\displaystyle L} over C {\displaystyle \mathbb {C} } equipped with a bilinear operator [ ⋅ , ⋅ ] : L × L → L {\displaystyle [\cdot ,\cdot ]\colon L\times L\rightarrow L} and linear maps ε : L → C {\displaystyle \varepsilon \colon L\to \mathbb {C} } (some authors use | ⋅ | : L → C {\displaystyle |\cdot |\colon L\to \mathbb {C} } ) and Δ : L → L ⊗ L {\displaystyle \Delta \colon L\to L\otimes L} such that Δ X = X i ⊗ X i {\displaystyle \Delta X=X_{i}\otimes X^{i}} , satisfying following axioms:[1]
